title: SCC’s planned approach to information sharing.

content:
Dear Sheffield City Council,
On 22 December 2019 I submitted FOI.
Between 22 December 2019 and March 2020 there appears to have been communication with Amey regarding my request about the regarding the contents of the email box associated with the former Director of Culture and Environment 1438. It appears from documents released so far there were discussions between Amey and SCC to discuss the statutory duty of information sharing and a "planned approach".
It seems there was no public consultation or information shared publicly on the council website regarding "SCC’s planned approach to information sharing". This request hopes to find more information on this "planned approach to information sharing", I wasn't aware of it before hand. Or that there was a consultation on it.
“As we’ve previously stated back in March we explained our concerns and reasoning behind rejecting the councils intent to share further information.” - RE: FOI REQUESTS - 1369 and 1438, 22 July 2020 11:11
“directly discuss the nature of our concerns and despite this have not heard back from the Council since writing to you early in March. "
1. Other than Amey, please identify  how many external parties SCC has consulted with regards to "SCC’s planned approach to information sharing".
2. Please identify and provide any recorded information between 22 December 2019 - July 22 2020, where any part of the document is in relation to the following statement: “concerns and reasoning behind rejecting the councils intent to share further information” in association to request 1438 or any other future FOI request.
“Ill wait to hear back re a meeting/call but do feel much of our we’d hope can be addressed thro’ gaining a better insight into SCC’s planned approach to information sharing” - 22 July 2020
3. Please provide any correspondence, memoranda, documents, reports, records, statements, notes, examinations, opinions, folders, files, manuals, pamphlets, forms, drawings, charts, photographs, electronic mail, and other documents and things that refer of relate to the following “SCC’s planned approach to information sharing” as discussed with Amey in relation to FOI 1369 & 1438 and FOI requests in the future. I believe there was a meeting between Amey and SCC the requested documents should be in relation to that meeting.
4. Please identify and provide the earliest correspondence SCC sent to Amey in relation to my request 1438, please provide any replies and subsequent discussions around 1438 between these two parties.
5. Please identify the date the FOI time had received the information from record custodians for 1438.
6. Please identify and provide records from that could show the requestor the delay from the time indicated in (5.) to the completed decision notice in relation to 1438.
Yours faithfully,
Marcus Combie

Dear Marcus Combie,
Thank you for your request for information relating to further information
about request 2019-20-1438 which we received on 28/09/2020.
This has been logged as a Freedom of Information Request, and will be
dealt with under the Freedom of Information Act 2000. The reference number
for your request can be found above.
Please be aware that Sheffield City Council’s response to the global
COVID-19 pandemic has led to a reduction in resources across the Council,
meaning that we are currently dealing with a backlog of requests.
We will aim to respond to your request within 20 working days, by
26/10/2020, but we kindly ask for your patience as we anticipate that
there may be a delay in some cases. Please do not hesitate to contact us
at the email address below if you have any queries.
Yours sincerely,
Sheffield City Council
PO Box 1283
Sheffield, S1 1UJ
Email: [1][Sheffield City Council request email]
P Please don't print this e-mail unless you really need to
show quoted sections

Dear FOI,
Is there any update on this? It’s overdue and most (but not all) of the documents requested should be held by the FOI as team for working documents, the request was about how the council a named third party Amey and possibly other unknown parties discussed the statutory responses to FOI requests.
Yours sincerely,
Marcus Combie

Dear Mr Combie
Thank you for your email and apologies for the delay in our reply. I can confirm that we do have the documents, but we need to review them before we issue our response. The reason for the delay is that we are still dealing with a large backlog of cases and have a shortage of staff, which means that it is taking longer than normal to respond to requests. We will try to prioritise dealing with your request as acknowledge that our response is overdue.
Kind regards
Robert Jackson
Access to Information Officer
Information Management Team
Business Change and Information Solutions
Resources Portfolio
Sheffield City Council
Email: [
email address
]; [Sheffield City Council request email];
[
email address
]; [
email address
]
Postal Address: Sheffield City Council, PO Box 1283 Sheffield S1 1UJ
show quoted sections

Dear FOI,
Can I please have an update on this request.
Can you please indicate when an initial response will be due?
This material is now especially relevant to any discussions I have with the archivist regarding the Street Tree Archive.
This records requested are fundamental in understanding how SCC and Amey approached Their statutory duty to information sharing.
My observations from Gleadless Valley FOI is that there was a lot of  unnecessary interference from officer not in the information management department in how that request was handled - it should not have taken so long.
I have complaints against Gillian Duckworth and other members of CEX can you please ensure they are no involved any further handling of my requests until those investigations are complete.
Yours sincerely,
Marcus Combie

Dear FOI,
Could you plwSe provide an update for this request.
I note on the public what do they know site.  Request “Information about your dealings with Stonewall CYPS [Extraneous material removed]“ which was submitted on the 14th February.
That is 5 months after my request.
That request recieved a response from SCC on 6August 2021 stating “We aim to provide a response by the end of next week.“
Why is a request that was submitted 5 months after
Mine recieving a response before?
Especially when you stated back in February to
Myself:
“I can confirm that we do have the documents, but we need to review them before we issue our response”
Could the council explain why requests are not been processed in the order they were recieved and why some requests are been filled early than others despite been submitted after.
Yours sincerely,
Marcus Combie

Dear FOI,
This request is approaching a year old.
Other requests submitted after this request have been completed to and responded to, for example Lee Armstrong and the cobbled street On Western Road. That request was submitted on 7th June and a response was issue on the 17th September.
Can the council please explain the delay in this request, why other requests that came in after this request are been processed before it.
The council confirmed the documents relevant to the request had been recieved on the 17th February.
Yours sincerely,
Marcus Combie

Dear FOI,
Can you please an update when a response will be due to this very overdue request.
The council were able to provide a hard date for a response to Michael Kenworthy request on  the 4 November 2021, for the request Penistone Road Cycle Way - Upgrade proposals Submitted September 2021.
However the council inactive on this request. Can you please provide the current status and when a response will be due, the same service offered to Michael Kenworthy.
Yours sincerely,
Marcus Combie

Dear FOI,
Followed up with a call to the FOI office and answer phone message left, request an update on this FOI by Friday.
Yours sincerely,
Marcus Combie

Dear Mr Combie
We apologise sincerely for the delay to this response. We have been
working off and on a response to you, which we will now focus on fully
with a target of providing a fortnight today.
We thank you for your patience.
Kind regards,
Sheffield City Council
PO Box 1283
Sheffield, S1 1UJ

Can I have an initial response. Or a deadline of when this request will be complete.
Yours sincerely,
Marcus Combie

We shall pick up the processing of it again on 21 February and update you

Dear FOI,
Please provide the cause as to the delay of this request.
Are there issues surrounding the standards complaint on emails been marked not subject to FOI?
Other FOIs have been submitted and responded to in full by the council from by other parties during the time this FOI has gone unaswered.
The records should be hard to locate, as some of this information was partially provided to Justin Buxton in their FOI.
Could the council please identify the cause of this delay to this request, and why others that have been submitted later than this have received a response, while this request remains without an initial response.
Yours sincerely,
Marcus Combie

Dear FOI,
Just confirming the conversation I had with Leon Kaplan.
I understand that the council stated there is no delay in handling requeats because of their subject i.e trees.
The council reached out to amey in September 21 to have discussions about this request, Amey have responded. The council has taken no further action to have these discussions.
Assurances were sought from Leon Kaplan that the dicussions should start immediately.
-
The council also umprompted mentioned another FOI Domain of senders and recipients of emails 2020-21 – FOI 2641 and informed that a response will be forthcoming this week.
-
I asked how the backlog  of FOI was been sorted through.
I was informed “randomly”.
Yours sincerely,
Marcus Combie

Dear Mr Combie
We apologise for the delay in responding to this internal review which you
requested on 16 February 2022 and would have been due on 18 March 2022. We
had said to you on 15 February 2022 that we were trying to respond to the
request by 28 February 2022.
It is an internal review because we failed to respond to your original
request on 26 September 2020. The response was due on 26 October 2020.
There was correspondence between us throughout 2021. We have breached
section 10(1) of the FOIA, which requires a response within 20 working
days. We have breached the Code of Practice under Section 45 of the Act
(para 5.4) by failing to acknowledge your request for an internal review
or provide in within 20 working days of receipt.
Our resources were squeezed by the pandemic. We regret our shortcomings
and are making every attempt to tackle our backlog and prevent the
situation from arising again. We uphold your complaint.
The rest of this response is to the original request you made on 26
September 2020.
It seems easiest to us to provide our responses in line with your requests
(in red). The square brackets are ours.
[Background supplied by you]
On 22 December 2019 I submitted FOI [2019-20-1438]
Between 22 December 2019 and March 2020 there appears to have been
communication with Amey regarding my request about the regarding the
contents of the email box associated with the former Director of Culture
and Environment 1438. It appears from documents released so far there were
discussions between Amey and SCC to discuss the statutory duty of
information sharing and a "planned approach".
It seems there was no public consultation or information shared publicly
on the council website regarding "SCC’s planned approach to information
sharing". This request hopes to find more information on this "planned
approach to information sharing", I wasn't aware of it before hand. Or
that there was a consultation on it.
“As we’ve previously stated back in March we explained our concerns and
reasoning behind rejecting the councils intent to share further
information.” - RE: FOI REQUESTS - 1369 and 1438, 22 July 2020 11:11
“directly discuss the nature of our concerns and despite this have not
heard back from the Council since writing to you early in March. "
1. Other than Amey, please identify how many external parties SCC has
consulted with regards to "SCC’s planned approach to information sharing".
None.
2. Please identify and provide any recorded information between 22
December 2019 - July 22 2020, where any part of the document is in
relation to the following statement: “concerns and reasoning behind
rejecting the councils intent to share further information” in association
to request 1438 or any other future FOI request.
We do not hold any information other than that which we have already
provided in our response to FOI 2020-21-2390 submitted by Mr Buxton:
[1]
https://www.whatdotheyknow.com/request/o...
Some of the information we released in our response to FOI 2020-21-2390
was subject to redaction for the following reasons, and we maintain that
those reasons apply to this request. For reference, the exemptions we
applied were:
Section 40(2) exempts information in response to a request if it is
personal data belonging to an individual other than yourself and it
satisfies one of the conditions listed in the legislation. (1) The
condition contained in section 40(3A)(a) applies, that disclosure would
breach one of the data protection principles. The principle is that
“Personal data shall be processed lawfully, fairly and in a transparent
manner...” (2) We do not consider that disclosing this information to you,
and consequently the public, is necessary or justified to satisfy your
information request and the requirements of the FOIA. In the circumstances
of this request there is no strong legitimate interest that would override
the prejudice to the rights and freedoms of the data subjects. We have
therefore taken the decision that disclosing this information to you would
be unlawful.
(1) Amendments to the Freedom of Information Act 2000 contained in the
Data Protection Act 2018.
(2) GDPR EU2016, Article 5(1)(a).
Please note that some information was redacted under section 42 of the
Freedom of Information Act 2000 on the grounds that this information is
subject to legal professional privilege. Section 42 is a qualified
exemption which is subject to a public interest test. Factors in favour of
disclosing the information are that disclosure promotes openness and
transparency. Factors in favour of maintaining the exception are that it
is important to protect the concept of legal professional privilege and
the rationale behind the concept, which is to safeguard frankness between
lawyer and client, and this serves the wider administration of justice. On
balance, the Council believes that the public interest lies in maintaining
the exception.
“Ill wait to hear back re a meeting/call but do feel much of our we’d hope
can be addressed thro’ gaining a better insight into SCC’s planned
approach to information sharing” - 22 July 2020
3. Please provide any correspondence, memoranda, documents, reports,
records, statements, notes, examinations, opinions, folders, files,
manuals, pamphlets, forms, drawings, charts, photographs, electronic mail,
and other documents and things that refer of relate to the following
“SCC’s planned approach to information sharing” as discussed with Amey in
relation to FOI 1369 & 1438 and FOI requests in the future. I believe
there was a meeting between Amey and SCC the requested documents should be
in relation to that meeting.
Please see 20200917_Principles for good communications between Amey PLC &
Sheffield City Council (SCC) regarding tree related FOIA_EIR requests
(attached).
Please note the redaction is subject to the exemption for personal data
set out in Q2 above.
4. Please identify and provide the earliest correspondence SCC sent to
Amey in relation to my request 1438, please provide any replies and
subsequent discussions around 1438 between these two parties.
Emails from March 2020
See attached: RE_ Freedom of Information requests 1369 & 1438 - WITHOUT
PREJUDICE AND SUBJECT TO COMMON INTEREST PRIVILEGE - NOT SUBJECT TO FOIA
Emails from after the disclosure (4 September 2020)
See attached: RE_ Confidential - Commercially Sensitive - Subject to
Common Interest Privilege - Without prejudice
(Not included in the email thread is the attachment provided in (3) above
which is otherwise part of it).
Please note the redactions of senders and recipients and other personal
information is subject to the exemption for personal data set out in Q2
above.
We have withheld information from an email of 15 September 2020 6:05 PM.
This information is exempt from disclosure under section 42(1) of the
Freedom of Information Act 2000 because it is subject to legal
professional privilege (LPP). LPP protects the confidentiality of legally
related communications. In this case, communications between Amey and the
Council are caught by the exemption.
This exemption is subject to a public interest test. Factors in favour of
disclosing the information are that disclosure promotes openness and
transparency. Factors in favour of maintaining the exception are that it
is important to protect the concept of legal professional privilege and
the rationale behind the concept, which is to safeguard frankness between
lawyer and client. On balance, the Council believes that the public
interest lies in maintaining the exemption.
We included everything else (subject to redactions) in the response to
2020-21-2390. See response to Q2.
5. Please identify the date the FOI time had received the information from
record custodians for 1438.
We obtained access to the relevant emails on 6 January 2020.
6. Please identify and provide records from that could show the requestor
the delay from the time indicated in (5.) to the completed decision notice
in relation to 1438.
From 6 January to 6 March, we were working on reviewing what information
fell within scope of the request and making any necessary redactions.
From 6 March to 17 March, we were trying to organise a meeting with Amey
to consult them on the disclosure.
In the week commencing 17 March, the first lockdown began. During this
time, the Council had to consider the redeployment of staff to keep
critical services running. For some time, the Information Management Team
were diverted to work to provide a large number of staff with IT equipment
to enable them to work properly from home, which had an impact on the
processing of FOI and SAR requests. In addition, staff changes placed
additional workload on members of the Information Management Team over the
summer. These delays meant the meeting with Amey took place on 29 July.
Following the meeting, we needed to review the documents we had prepared
for disclosure, which took a further four-five weeks due to staff being
leave, and because of having to complete other work. A response was issued
on 4 September 2020.
If you have any queries about this response, please do not hesitate to
contact us.
The information provided in this response is available for re-use under
the terms of the Open Government Licence v3.0. The terms of the OGL can be
found [2]here. When re-using the information, Sheffield City Council
requires you to include the following attribution statement: “Contains
public sector information obtained from Sheffield City Council and
licensed under the Open Government Licence v3.0.”
If you are unhappy with the response you have received in relation to your
request, you are entitled to have this reviewed. You can ask for an
internal review by replying to this email. Internal review requests should
be submitted within 40 working days from the date of this response.
If you remain dissatisfied with the outcome of your internal review, you
can contact the Information Commissioner’s Office. Please see
[3]
https://ico.org.uk/make-a-complaint/offi...
for further details.
Kind Regards,
Sheffield City Council
PO Box 1283
Sheffield, S1 1UJ
